content:
SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that after the attacks on Pearl Harbor, Imperial Japanese forces cut off communication to the Armed Forces and Filipino troops in the Far East. Corregidor fell on May 6, 1942, followed by the surrender of American forces on May 10, 1942, on the island of Mindanao. In April 1942, General Wainwright surrendered Allied Forces in the Philippine Archipelago. Despite being cut off, troops bravely defended Bataan for over 4 months, changing the war's momentum and delaying the Japanese invasion. During the Bataan Death March in April 1942, Major General Edward King surrendered troops from the United States and the Philippines to the enemy. Thousands of soldiers were taken prisoner and forced to march 65 miles without food, water, or medical care, resulting in many deaths from starvation, lack of medical care, and exhaustion. Conditions at the prisoner of war camps, particularly Camp O'Donnell, were appalling, leading to high death rates due to disease and malnutrition. Nearly 26,000 Filipino prisoners died at Camp O'Donnell, with survivors gradually paroled from September to December 1942. Survivors of the death march were later shipped north for forced labor between September 1942 and December 1944. During World War II, prisoners of war were subjected to horrific conditions, including forced labor on "hell ships" where many perished. The sinking of the Arisan Maru alone claimed nearly 1,800 lives. The University of Santo Tomas was converted into an internment camp by the Japanese, where army and navy nurses were held until their liberation. Prisoners in the camps endured mistreatment, malnutrition, and lack of medical care. The veterans of Bataan endured mistreatment, malnutrition, and lack of medical care until their liberation in 1945. They represented diversity and were honored in memorials. The US Navy named ships after them, including the USS Bataan (LHD-5), in memory of their valor against Japanese forces. Many survivors have passed away. Many survivors of Bataan have passed away, but those remaining continue to share their stories. The US and Philippines are grateful for their courage during WWII and their perseverance during years of captivity. The US and Philippines are grateful for the courage of Bataan survivors during WWII and their perseverance during years of captivity. Congressional Gold Medal. The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will award a single gold medal to American military personnel who fought in defense of Bataan, Corregidor, Guam, Wake Island, and the Philippine Archipelago during WWII and were imprisoned by the Japanese military. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Following the award of the gold medal to American military personnel who fought in WWII, the medal will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research. Congress suggests that the Institution should also make the medal available for display at other locations associated with the honored personnel. SEC. 3. DUPLICATE MEDALS.

(a) The Secretary may strike bronze duplicates of the gold medal under section 2 and sell them to cover costs.
(b) Proceeds from the sale of duplicates shall be deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund.

SEC. 4. STATUS OF MEDALS.

(a) Medals under this Act are national medals.
(b) All medals are considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code.

SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations up to $30,000 from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund for the authorized medal under section 2.
